div.head: Calais
div.p: Tuesday, May 14th, 1833. We arrived at Calais after a passage of considerable roughness, the sea being in a state of great agitation. The English Channel, which had seemed so narrow upon the map, proved itself a formidable barrier when crossed in person.

The town of Calais presented itself with all the novelty of a foreign land. The houses, built of a grey stone quite unlike our London brick, rose in irregular lines along the quay. The douane officers examined our luggage with the most tedious meticulous attention to detail.

The Hotel Dessein, where we took our lodging, was a building of some antiquity and considerable reputation among English travellers. Sterne had staidstayed here, and the memory of his Sentimental Journey gave the place an air of literary distinction.

lg.l: The waves upon the foreign shore
And all the landscape spread before
Was new and strange, yet sweetly found.
The spires of Calais caught the light
Of evening in a golden haze,
And promised to our eager sight
The wonders of the coming days.

div.p: We walked through the old town in the evening, observing the place d’armes and the fortifications which had once withstood the siege of Edward III in 1347. The walls, though much reduced from their former strength, still conveyed an impression of medieval solidity.

div.head: On the Road to Paris
div.p: Wednesday, May 15th. We departed Calais early in the morning by diligence, the great lumbering coach of the French roads. The countryside of Picardy unfolded itself in long flat stretches of farmland, punctuated by rows of Lombardy poplars that stood like sentinels along every road.

At Boulogne we paused briefly. The cliff scenery reminded me of our own Dover cliffs, though the geological formations Ruskin's early interest in geology is evident throughout the journal, prefiguring his later scientific writings. showed distinct differences in their stratification. I made several sketches in my notebook, attempting to capture the arrangement of the chalk layers.
The road to Paris stretched before us, and with it the promise of adventures yet to come. My father spoke of the Louvre with such enthusiasm that I could scarcely contain my excitement anticipation.
